subject: Religion & Spirituality
title: Islam's Golden Age of Knowledge
description: A quick, practical guide to Islam's Golden Age of Knowledge.

hook.text: While Europe languished in the Dark Ages, Islamic scholars invented algebra, advanced optics, and preserved Greek texts.

buildup.text: From the 8th to 14th centuries, the Islamic world led global science. Baghdad's House of Wisdom was the world's library.

discovery.text: Al-Khwarizmi invented algebra. Ibn al-Haytham pioneered optics. Ibn Sina wrote the medical textbook used for 600 years.

twist.text: Europe's Renaissance was built on Islamic translations. Without Muslim scholars, Aristotle might have been lost.

climax.text: Islam's golden age proves that faith and science once thrived together. The conflict narrative is a modern invention.

punchline.text: Algebra, optics, and modern medicine. Islam's golden age built modern science.

quiz.question: What was the House of Wisdom?
options: A major library and translation center in Baghdad
